x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement:
In community home/long-term care (LTC) and community health settings, early identification of residents who need palliative care is often delayed. Paper-based assessments and inconsistent communication between care teams lead to missed opportunities for comfort-focused interventions. This causes unnecessary suffering for residents, increased distress for families, and inefficient coordination among nurses, physicians, and personal support workers.
The current process depends on manual reviews and fragmented documentation, which makes it difficult to track residents’ changing conditions in real time and trigger timely palliative consultations.

How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

ServiceNow products or capabilities used:

App Engine Studio – create the custom Palliative Assessment application, tables, and forms.
Flow Designer – automate assessment scoring, review routing, and notifications.
Service Portal / Mobile App – allow bedside assessments on tablets or mobile devices.
Performance Analytics – monitor metrics such as number of active palliative residents and time to initiate care plans.
IntegrationHub (Spokes) – connect with existing EHR or LTC resident systems via REST, HTTP, or CSV spokes.
API Designer & Inbound REST APIs – expose endpoints for external systems to send resident updates or request assessment data.
Notification & Event Management – push alerts to care teams when assessment scores cross a defined threshold.
Data Policies & Access Control Rules – ensure role-based data protection for sensitive health information.
Document Management / Attachments – store digital copies of physician notes or family consent forms.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

Technical dependencies:

  • Integration with resident data from an Electronic Health Record (EHR) or  PointOfCare(POC) (e.g., CSV import or REST API).
  • Role-based access integration with staff directory (Active Directory or local user table).

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

Anticipated challenges:

  • Aligning assessment criteria with clinical standards used across facilities.
  • Ensuring data privacy and HIPAA/PHIPA compliance for sensitive health information.
  • Driving adoption among staff who are used to paper-based workflows.
  • Managing integration consistency with various LTC systems that differ in structure and data quality.
